content.title: Common Femoral Artery Disease
content.definition: Atherosclerotic disease involving the common femoral artery (CFA), representing critical inflow disease that typically requires open surgical endarterectomy rather than endovascular intervention.

anatomy.location: From inguinal ligament to femoral bifurcation
anatomy.landmarks: Bifurcation usually 3-5 cm below inguinal ligament

symptoms: Inflow limitation to all downstream interventions

open_surgery_preferred.indication: CFA is considered last bastion of open surgery

endovascular_limitations: High stent fracture rates due to motion
Risk of thrombosis in flexion zone

endarterectomy_technique.arteriotomy: Longitudinal over CFA and into proximal SFA/profunda

learning_objectives: Explain why CFA disease is treated surgically
Recognize hybrid approach for multi-level disease
clinical_pearls: CFA is the last bastion of open vascular surgery
Never stent the CFA - flexion causes fracture/occlusion
Always assess profunda origin during CFE
